articles.title: Amid Sudan’s humanitarian crisis, Chad shows ‘act of solidarity’
articles.summary: In war-torn Sudan, local communities say they don’t have enough settlements for the internally displaced, few solutions for women who have suffered sexual violence – and there’s a lack of aid available for people with disabilities.
articles.content:
That’s according to UN human rights chief Volker Türk, who had discussions with over 40 leaders of Sudanese civil society in Northern State’s capital, Dongola, this week.

Tweet URL

“But these representatives have also found the solution,” Mr. Türk said in a video on X. “There needs to be an all-out effort, both within Sudan and by the international community to help them, to facilitate their work.”

The conflict in Sudan which erupted in 2023 between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the armed group Rapid Support Forces (RSF) has uprooted some 9.3 million people and has brought about one of the world’s largest hunger crises.

Mr. Türk began his visit on Wednesday and is meeting with Sudanese authorities, civil society, humanitarian partners and people displaced by the conflict in Darfur and Kordofan. He will be holding two press conferences at the end of his visit on 18 January.

Chad shows ‘act of solidarity’

Since April 2023, more than 900,000 Sudanese refugees have arrived in eastern Chad, with new arrivals every day, the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) said on Friday.

The newly-appointed UN High Commissioner for Refugees Barham Salih visited Chad this week for the first time in this capacity, where he met with Sudanese refugee families and local authorities.

Many of the refugees he met had been displaced multiple times since the conflict began. They described years of violent attacks and human rights abuses.

“What is unfolding in Sudan is a humanitarian calamity of overwhelming scale. Chad’s generous welcome of refugees is a powerful act of solidarity,” Mr. Salih said.

From displacement to solutions

Mr. Salih also acknowledged the host communities that have welcomed refugees despite economic hardship and environmental pressure.

He reiterated UNHCR’s readiness to work with the Government and others to facilitate economic opportunity and provide services for both refugees and the host communities.

© UNHCR/Hélène Caux The UN Refugees chief, Barham Salih (centre), speaks with Sudanese refugees at a women's centre in Farchana, Chad.

“Visiting Chad and Kenya this last week, both countries clearly demonstrate how, with sustained international support, inclusive policies can move us from responding to displacement emergencies towards providing solutions,” Mr. Salih emphasised.

“When refugees are protected and included, they can rebuild their lives and contribute to the societies that host them. This is what I am seeing here, and this is the direction in which we must travel.”

**What happened** – Since April 2023, more than 900,000 Sudanese refugees have crossed into eastern Chad. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) chief, Barham Salih, recently visited Chad to meet these refugees and local leaders. He learned about the hardships refugees faced, including repeated displacement and violence. Despite tough economic and environmental conditions, Chad’s local communities have welcomed these refugees.

**Impact** – Chad’s openness to refugees is described as a strong act of kindness and support during a huge crisis. This generosity helps refugees find safety and a chance to rebuild their lives. articles.title: The peacemakers: Meet Venezuelans who are fighting to free political detainees
articles.summary: In Venezuela, relatives and human-rights NGOs have stepped up calls for the immediate release of more than 800 victims of politically-motivated persecution of the government formerly led by Nicolás Maduro.
articles.content:
While the world is engaged in heated debates — both on and offline — about the legality of Donald Trump’s January 3 military airstrikes in Venezuela, relatives and friends are fighting for the full release of loved ones from unjust imprisonment in the South American country.

On January 8, Jorge Rodríguez, head of the Venezuelan National Assembly (Asamblea Nacional), announced the release of a “significant number of imprisoned individuals,” as a “unilateral gesture” in the beleaguered country. However, the congressman did not provide an official release list.

Those detained are considered to be “victims of politically motivated persecution” by the government formerly led by Nicolás Maduro. This is part of a “long-standing and appalling human rights record” by the leadership, according to the United Nations-commissioned Fact-Finding Mission on the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, which has been active since 2019.

At least 863 people fell under the aforementioned criteria, according to an ongoing, long-term vetted tally by the Foro Penal, a Venezuelan human rights NGO. They are women and men from all backgrounds, including older adults, journalists, and foreigners.

However, as of 7.00 a.m. on January 16 (Venezuelan local time), the figures diverged on the number of released prisoners. Only 84 — out of more than their original vetted estimate of more than 800 — had been freed, according to Alfredo Romero, of Foro Penal. Half an hour later, Acting President Delcy Rodríguez set the release number to 406 during a press conference at Miraflores Palace in Caracas, the official seat of the Venezuelan presidency.

No names were provided by the acting president, who is the sister of the head of the Venezuelan National Assembly, Jorge Rodríguez.

It all starts with the family

Several independent advocacy groups are the protagonists of the local push for the release of Venezuelan political prisoners: the Committee for the Freedom of Political Prisoners in Venezuela (Comité por la Liberación de los Presos Políticos, CLIPPVE) and the Committee of Mothers for the Defense of the Truth (Comité de las Madres en Defensa de la Verdad), among others.

Relatives (especially women), supporters from the general public, and even former political prisoners participate in these activities. They have also brought food and medicines to their loved ones over the years, whenever visits were allowed inside prison facilities.

Their actions are not confined to a particular political affiliation. Last year, the then-active Committee for the Defense of the Venezuelan Migrants (Comité por la Defensa de los Migrantes Venezolanos) pushed for the return of the 252 Venezuelan migrants unjustly imprisoned by the Donald Trump and Nayib Bukele administrations at El Salvador’s infamous CECOT mega prison. Followers of Nicolás Maduro are also allegedly included among the people currently considered political prisoners in Venezuela.

The power of organization

“Organization is key for the defense of human rights,” said Marino Alvarado, attorney and activist, during an open meeting held in August 1, 2024 between families, human rights non-profits and press members at the Universidad Central de Venezuela in Caracas, held in the midst of the 2024 post-electoral repression.

“Let’s find each other, let’s get organized, and you will be better able to support your loved ones,” Alvarado then recommended. He spoke from lived experience, as the Demanding Coordinator for the Venezuelan Program for Education and Action in Human Rights (Provea), another renowned Venezuelan human rights NGO, founded in 1988.

By the end of the meeting, those words seemed to come alive. As the press was leaving the meeting that day, a group of relatives was observed around the table, carefully speaking with Alvarado and drafting ideas on paper. Some of those faces could be found later in activities of their own as the CLIPPVE, always carrying black fabric with a constant appeal in white lettering: Liberen A Los Presos Políticos (Free the Political Prisoners).

Nonviolence and immense courage shape the current actions of Venezuelan advocacy groups: candlelight vigils, prayers, pages of names of their loved ones, and camaraderie. In the past, some have even seen unprovoked attacks from unidentified groups, including the Committee of Mothers near the Venezuelan Supreme Court on August 5, 2025.

Families who are waiting near Venezuelan detention centers — confirmed releases have so far come without previous notice — now face spells of colder weather, lack of public transportation and scarce (open) support from outsiders. The fear of repressive practices by the current Delcy Rodríguez administration has not subsided.

They are soldiering on together, focusing on social media as their primary medium of communication, using hashtags such as #QueSeanTodos.

Future leaders for reconciliation?

Caring for loved ones persecuted for political reasons is not a new endeavor in Venezuela and other Latin American countries.

The long-term impact — both local and international — of a human rights activist group should not be overstated. The Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo (Abuelas de Plaza de Mayo), first founded in 1977 during Argentina’s last military dictatorship, organized themselves around the need to find the missing babies and small children of disappeared activists in the South American country.

They did not just become a fully-formed NGO within Argentina, but went beyond Argentine borders. For over 30 years, the grandmothers have collaborated with scientific non-profit teams such as the Argentine Forensic Anthropology Team (EAAF in Spanish), in order to identify formerly abducted children through genetics. To date, 140 adults have found their original identity, thanks to the Grandmothers.

The EAAF has helped solve other international cases, including Ayotzinapa/Iguala (Mexico) and El Mozote (El Salvador) massacres.

Back in Venezuela, the future aims of movements like CLIPPVE and the Committee of Mothers for the Defense of the Truth remain to be seen. However, their testimony will be a crucial step into a Venezuela that is in dire need of further work on human rights, especially on Memory, Justice and Democracy (Memoria, Justice and Democracy), as stated by Provea’s general coordinator, Oscar Murillo, on January 11:

Hemos tenido una semana avasallante en todos los sentidos… La historia aconseja dejar enfriar un poco las cosas para hilvanar análisis más exactos pero, sin duda, el #3Enero2026 marca el comienzo de una etapa no menos inestable y de muchas tensiones, la cual exige lo mejor de… — Oscar Murillo (@oscarfmurillo) January 12, 2026

**Context** – Venezuela has a history of imprisoning people for political reasons. More than 800 people are believed to be held as political prisoners under the government that followed Nicolás Maduro. Families and human rights groups have been working for years to get these people released.

While officials gave different numbers, around 400 detainees were freed by mid-January. Groups like the Committee for the Freedom of Political Prisoners in Venezuela (CLIPPVE) and the Committee of Mothers for the Defense of the Truth have played an important role in pushing for these releases through peaceful protests, visits, and public campaigns.

The participation of many people from different backgrounds, including former prisoners and supporters, highlights the strength of community in fighting unfair imprisonment. The work done by these groups also connects to a larger history of human rights activism in Latin America, reminding us that persistence matters.

**What's next step** – The groups will continue their work to free all political prisoners and seek justice. They use social media to share updates and organize support. Their ongoing efforts may help build a future in Venezuela where human rights are respected, and political freedom is stronger.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Families and human rights groups in Venezuela are making steady progress in freeing political prisoners through peaceful, organized activism.

articles.title: Use film-style age ratings to limit teens' social media, say Lib Dems
articles.summary: The Conservatives want to see ban of all under-16s from social media, but the Lib Dems say that would be a "blunt instrument".
articles.content:
Use film-style age ratings to limit teens' social media, say Lib Dems

18 hours ago Share Save Kate Whannel political reporter Share Save

Getty Images

The Liberal Democrats have proposed introducing film-style age ratings to limit which social media apps children can access. Under the party's plan, platforms that use addictive algorithmic feeds or host "inappropriate content" would be restricted to users over 16 years old, while sites with "graphic violence or pornography" would be rated 18-plus. This approach, the Lib Dems have argued, would "avoid the unintended consequences" of banning all under-16s from using social media, as advocated by the Conservatives. In recent days, Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer has indicated he is open to the idea of an outright ban, telling reporters that "all options are on the table".

He said he would be watching to see how a ban recently introduced in Australia was working. The new Australian law, which came into force in December, requires certain social media companies including Facebook, Snapchat, Instagram, X and TikTok to take "reasonable steps" to keep children off their platforms. In order to ascertain a user's age, the companies can use government-issued identity documents, face or voice recognition or analyse online behaviour to estimate a person's age. The Conservatives have said that, if elected, they would follow the same approach as the Australian government and ban under-16s from accessing social media. Tory leader Kemi Badenoch said: "The internet is a Wild West, social media in particular, we don't want children to be on there." However, Victoria Collins, the Liberal Democrats' science and technology spokesperson, said the proposal for a "blanket ban" was a "blunt instrument that doesn't work in a digital age". She said it showed Conservatives "just don't trust parents". The Liberal Democrats have argued that their "tailored approach" would allow governments to "quickly categorise" newly-emerging social media platforms based on the addictiveness or harmfulness of their content. Lib Dem leader Sir Ed Davey said: "Our message to social media giants is clear: if your platform spreads harmful content or relies on addictive and harmful algorithms, you should not be allowed anywhere near our children. "This issue cannot be kicked down the road any longer."
articles.reasoning: The article describes a policy proposal aimed at protecting children and teenagers from harmful social media content by introducing age-appropriate restrictions similar to film ratings. This approach promotes child welfare and responsible digital use, addressing a significant societal concern with a nuanced, potentially more effective method than outright bans. The proposal has broad public significance as it impacts youth safety and digital rights.
articles.personality_title: Lib Dems propose film-style age ratings to protect teens on social media
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Social media can expose children to harmful or inappropriate content. Some politicians want to ban all users under 16 from social media, but this has raised concerns about fairness and effectiveness.

**What happened** – The Liberal Democrats suggested using age ratings like those for movies to decide which social media apps children can use. Apps with addictive features or some bad content would be for users 16 and older. Apps showing graphic violence or adult content would be for 18 and older. This idea aims to be more precise than a total ban.

**Impact** – This plan tries to protect young people from harmful online content while still letting them use safer apps. It avoids the problems of blocking all teens from social media, which some say is too strict and doesn’t trust parents to decide what’s best. It also gives a way to rate new apps quickly based on their risks.

**What's next step** – Politicians will keep discussing the best ways to keep children safe online. The government may study how similar rules work in Australia, where companies must check users’ ages to keep kids off certain platforms. The Lib Dems want their rating system to be considered as a smarter alternative to full bans.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Liberal Democrats want to use movie-style age ratings to help protect children on social media without banning all under-16s.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les Libéraux-démocrates proposent des classifications d'âge à la manière du cinéma pour protéger les adolescents sur les réseaux sociaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les réseaux sociaux peuvent exposer les enfants à des contenus nuisibles ou inappropriés. Certains politiciens veulent interdire l'accès aux moins de 16 ans, mais cette idée soulève des questions d'équité et d'efficacité.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Les Libéraux-démocrates ont proposé d'utiliser des classifications d'âge comme pour les films afin de décider à quels réseaux sociaux les enfants peuvent accéder. Les applications avec des contenus addictifs ou certains contenus mauvais seraient réservées aux 16 ans et plus. Celles montrant de la violence graphique ou des contenus pour adultes seraient limitées aux plus de 18 ans. Cette idée vise à être plus précise qu'une interdiction totale.

**Impact** – Ce plan cherche à protéger les jeunes des contenus nuisibles en ligne tout en leur permettant d’utiliser des applications plus sûres. Il évite les problèmes d’une interdiction totale qui serait trop stricte et ne ferait pas confiance aux parents. Il offre aussi un moyen rapide d’évaluer les nouveaux réseaux sociaux selon leurs risques.

**Prochaine étape** – Les politiciens continueront à discuter des meilleures façons de protéger les enfants en ligne. Le gouvernement pourrait étudier comment fonctionnent des règles similaires en Australie, où les entreprises doivent vérifier l’âge des utilisateurs pour empêcher les enfants d’accéder à certaines plateformes. Les Libéraux-démocrates souhaitent que leur système de classification soit pris en compte comme une alternative plus intelligente aux interdictions totales.

**En résumé** – Les Libéraux-démocrates veulent utiliser des classifications d’âge comme au cinéma pour protéger les enfants sur les réseaux sociaux sans interdire tous les moins de 16 ans.
articles.personality_title_es: Los liberales demócratas proponen clasificaciones de edad al estilo del cine para proteger a los adolescentes en redes sociales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las redes sociales pueden exponer a los niños a contenidos dañinos o inapropiados. Algunos políticos quieren prohibir el acceso a menores de 16 años, pero esta medida genera dudas sobre su justicia y efectividad.

**Qué pasó** – Los liberales demócratas sugirieron usar clasificaciones de edad similares a las del cine para decidir a qué redes sociales pueden acceder los niños. Las aplicaciones con contenido adictivo o inapropiado serían para mayores de 16 años, y las con violencia gráfica o contenido para adultos, solo para mayores de 18. Esta idea busca ser más precisa que una prohibición total.

**Impacto** – Este plan intenta proteger a los jóvenes de contenido dañino mientras les permite usar aplicaciones más seguras. Evita los problemas de bloquear a todos los menores de 16 años, algo que algunos consideran demasiado estricto y que no confía en los padres. También ofrece una forma rápida de clasificar nuevas aplicaciones según su riesgo.

**Próximo paso** – Los políticos seguirán debatiendo sobre cómo proteger mejor a los niños en línea. El gobierno podría estudiar cómo funcionan reglas similares en Australia, donde las empresas deben verificar la edad para impedir el acceso de niños a ciertas plataformas. Los liberales demócratas quieren que se considere su sistema de clasificación como una alternativa más inteligente a las prohibiciones totales.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Los liberales demócratas proponen usar clasificaciones de edad al estilo del cine para proteger a los niños en redes sociales sin prohibir a todos los menores de 16 años.

articles.title: Appeal by EPP group leader Weber: EU embassies should become safe havens
articles.summary: The President of the European Parliament, Roberta Metsola, is calling for more support for the protesters in Iran. The head of the European People's Party (EPP) group, Manfred Weber, is making a concrete proposal.
articles.content:
The President of the European Parliament, Roberta Metsola, is calling for more support for the protesters in Iran. The head of the European People’s Party (EPP) group, Manfred Weber, is making a concrete proposal.

Berlin (dpa) – In view of the violence against demonstrators in Iran, the German European politician Manfred Weber is calling for the remaining EU embassies in the country to be opened to persecuted Iranians. “We must protect them from the terror regime. Let us open all embassies of EU countries in Iran as shelters, so that the peaceful demonstrators can find refuge there,” said the head of the conservative European People’s Party (EPP) group in the European Parliament to the newspaper “Bild”. “The deadly violence of the mullah regime against peaceful demonstrators cannot be justified in any way. The courageous opposition in Iran deserves our full support,” the politician explained his initiative.

Previously, the President of the European Parliament, Roberta Metsola, had demanded significantly stronger support from the governments of the EU member states for the protests against the state leadership in Iran. Metsola herself had already banned all official representatives of the Islamic Republic of Iran from entering the premises of the European Parliament on Monday.

According to the human rights organization Hengaw, more than 2,500 people have lost their lives in Iran since the protests began. Iran’s security apparatus is systematically cracking down on the mass protests. The protests have now subsided. (January 14)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a concrete political initiative by EU leaders to protect persecuted protesters in Iran by opening EU embassies as safe havens, representing a meaningful and tangible action to support human rights and provide refuge from violence. The story focuses on a significant humanitarian response with broad societal impact, backed by detailed context.
articles.personality_title: EU leaders propose using embassies as safe havens for Iranian protesters
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many people in Iran have been protesting against their government, but these protests have been met with violence. Over 2,500 protesters have died, and the security forces are cracking down hard on those who speak out.

**What happened** – Manfred Weber, leader of the European People's Party (EPP) in the European Parliament, suggested that the remaining European Union (EU) embassies in Iran should open their doors to protect these protesters. This means the embassies would act as safe places where people can find refuge from danger. Roberta Metsola, the President of the European Parliament, also called for stronger support from EU countries and banned Iranian officials from entering the Parliament building.

**Impact** – This idea is important because it offers a real way to help people facing violence. Embassies are usually protected by international law, so they can provide safety where other places cannot. By turning embassies into shelters, the EU shows it is willing to take concrete steps to protect human rights and support peaceful protesters.

**What's next step** – The EU member countries will need to discuss and decide if they will agree to open their embassies as safe havens. If they do, the embassies will prepare to welcome and protect people in danger, which could save many lives and send a strong message against violence.

**One-sentence takeaway** – EU leaders propose turning embassies in Iran into safe places to protect protesters facing violence from their government.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les dirigeants de l’UE proposent de transformer les ambassades en refuges pour les manifestants iraniens

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Manfred Weber, chef du Parti populaire européen (PPE) au Parlement européen, a proposé que les ambassades restantes de l’Union européenne (UE) en Iran ouvrent leurs portes pour protéger ces manifestants. Roberta Metsola, présidente du Parlement européen, a également demandé un soutien plus fort des pays de l’UE et a interdit aux représentants iraniens d’entrer dans le bâtiment du Parlement.

**Impact** – Cette idée est importante car elle offre un moyen concret d’aider les personnes qui subissent la violence. Les ambassades sont généralement protégées par le droit international, elles peuvent donc offrir une sécurité là où d’autres lieux ne le peuvent pas. En transformant les ambassades en refuges, l’UE montre qu’elle est prête à agir pour protéger les droits humains et soutenir les manifestants pacifiques.

articles.personality_title_es: Líderes de la UE proponen convertir embajadas en refugios para manifestantes iraníes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchas personas en Irán han estado protestando contra su gobierno, pero estas protestas han sido respondidas con violencia. Más de 2,500 manifestantes han muerto, y las fuerzas de seguridad están reprimiendo fuertemente a quienes se expresan.

**Qué pasó** – Manfred Weber, líder del Partido Popular Europeo (PPE) en el Parlamento Europeo, propuso que las embajadas restantes de la Unión Europea (UE) en Irán abran sus puertas para proteger a estos manifestantes. Esto significa que las embajadas actuarían como lugares seguros donde las personas pueden refugiarse del peligro. Roberta Metsola, presidenta del Parlamento Europeo, también pidió un apoyo más fuerte de los países de la UE y prohibió la entrada de representantes iraníes al Parlamento.

**Impacto** – Esta idea es importante porque ofrece una forma real de ayudar a personas que enfrentan violencia. Las embajadas suelen estar protegidas por la ley internacional, por lo que pueden brindar seguridad donde otros lugares no pueden. Al convertir las embajadas en refugios, la UE demuestra que está dispuesta a tomar medidas concretas para proteger los derechos humanos y apoyar a los manifestantes pacíficos.

**Próximo paso** – Los países miembros de la UE tendrán que discutir y decidir si aceptan abrir sus embajadas como refugios. Si lo hacen, las embajadas se prepararán para recibir y proteger a las personas en peligro, lo que podría salvar muchas vidas y enviar un mensaje fuerte contra la violencia.

**Frase clave** – Los líderes de la UE proponen convertir embajadas en Irán en lugares seguros para proteger a manifestantes que enfrentan violencia de su gobierno.
